awd_titl_txt: Dynamic Network Analysis: Analyzing the Chronnectome
awd_abstract_narration:
Networks describe interactions between objects: they can for example describe connections between people, as in social networks; capture dependencies in biological processes such as gene regulation; or represent the interplay and connectivity of different structural and functional areas in the brain. Numerous methods for network analysis have been developed using different quantitative approaches. However, many of these methods are still predominantly available for the analysis of static networks, i.e., snapshots of a network at a particular point in time. However, to assess how networks such as those in the brain change over time, improved methods for dynamic network analysis are required. This project will develop mathematical approaches motivated by the driving biological problem of analyzing temporal change of structural and functional brain connectivity, the chronnectome. Structural connectivity includes white matter connections in the brain and hence the underlying cabling enabling information exchange. Functional brain connectivity on the other hand describes how tasks influence brain activity and how different brain areas behave similarly under tasks. Quantifying changes in structural and/or functional connectivity over time can improve understanding of brain diseases, which deviate from normality. Moreover, the approaches developed here will have general use for other dynamic networks, from other biological networks to social networks and beyond. To maximize impact, the computational methods developed here will be made available in open-source form, with a software license permitting free commercial and non-commercial use. The project also includes research training and courses for students in network science.

Networks are commonly described as graphs, with nodes describing entities in a system and edges node relationships. Networks range from unstructured and rapidly changing social networks to structured slowly varying networks capturing structural brain connectivity. Network science seeks to develop methods to mine information from interaction patterns, for example, extracting tightly coupled nodes in communities. Time-dependent network data is increasingly available; however, sufficient analysis methods are still lacking as the majority of approaches have focused on static data, with ongoing development of methods for time-dependent networks having become more common only recently. The goal of this project is to advance general time-dependent network analysis, with brain chronnectome analysis as the guiding driving problem to motivate the technical development. Current approaches for the analysis of time-dependent networks lack several key properties required for chronnectome analysis: e.g., (i) the ability to analyze longitudinal network data, where networks are available for multiple subjects at multiple timepoints, (ii) the ability to include domain-specific prior information (such as prior knowledge of connectivity patterns), and (iii) the ability to deal with inhomogeneous subject groups and discontinuities in time. To address these shortcomings, this project will develop customized network analysis approaches based on (i) extensions to the stochastic block model approach of network analysis, and (ii) regression models for network-valued data.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
Structural and functional brain connectivity can be studied in various ways: for example, using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or electroencephalography (EEG).  This connectivity information can be represented as time-dependent networks. While a variety of analysis approaches for static networks have been developed, approaches for the analysis of time-dependent networks are much more recent. 

Intellectual merit: This project developed general computational tools for the analysis of time-varying networks. Specifically, we developed approaches for the following network analysis tasks. 1) Network compression: Analyzing large networks is oftentimes computationally costly. We developed an approach for representing a network with a smaller number of "supernodes", allowing for more compact network representations and faster computations. 2) Attributed networks: Networks may not only represent connectivity, but may also have attributes (e.g., in a social network connectivity might represent the collection of one’s friends and an attribute could be income, height, or age). We developed approaches to incorporate continuous attributes into a network description and, in particular, into a stochastic block model (SBM) which is a statistical model to capture network subgroups. 3) Statistical testing: A key question of an attributed SBM is if there is evidence that node attributes align with network connectivity (and hence might inform SBM grouping). We developed an approach to test for such evidence. 4) Temporal networks: We developed novel temporal network block models. In particular, we developed models which account for expected properties in brain networks, such as expected group structure and expected edge correlation. 5) Network metrics and representations: We also investigated new metrics to characterize temporal networks that generalize existing notions of network community flexibility (essentially, how network nodes change assigned groups over time) as well as using deep-learning approaches to obtain more discriminative network representations. This allowed us to develop network classification models for memory tasks observed via EEG. Applications: We applied our approaches to different kinds of network data and developed them in the context of these respective applications. Specifically, we applied them to longitudinal data of structural connectivity (obtained via diffusion weighted magnetic resonance imaging) in macaques and humans to characterize neurodevelopment. We also extensively applied and developed our approaches on EEG data to study human memory tasks.

Broader impact: While our methods are motivated by the analysis of the time-dependent brain networks, our invented approaches are expected to be applicable for the general analysis of time-varying networks, ranging from problems involving social networks to network data in biology and medicine. For maximal flexibility and to assure utility of our approaches in other application domains we made our methods available to the community in open-source form. This will allow others to adapt approaches, to replicate our results, and to create customized network analysis approaches building on top of the methods we invented as part of this project.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/15/2021
Modified by: Marc Niethammer
